perturbation.changed_text: Ginkgo shall pay all undisputed amounts under an invoice received from BLI under this Section 2.4.2 (Payment) within 60 days after receipt of such BLI invoice, and any overdue payments on undisputed amounts shall be subject to payment of interest pursuant to Section 7.10 (Late Payment). perturbation.explanation: California law requires payments to small businesses to be made within 30 days, unless otherwise stipulated in the contract. By extending the payment term to 60 days, the contract creates non-compliance with state regulatory standards if Ginkgo is considered a small business.

perturbation.original_text: 10.2 Confidential Treatment. At all times during the Term and for a period of [***] ([***]) years following the end of the Term, or with respect to trade secrets (with such trade secrets either (i) having been specifically identified in writing to the Receiving Party by the Disclosing Party claiming ownership of the same or (ii) reasonably distinguishable by its nature or content as a trade secret of the Disclosing Party), until such time that such information is no longer a trade secret (including pursuant to Sections 10.1.1 - 10.1.5), Receiving Party will, and will cause its Affiliates and its and their respective officers, directors, employees, Permitted Subcontractors, permitted sublicensees and agents to, keep confidential and not publish or otherwise disclose to a Third Party and not use for any purpose, any Confidential Information furnished or otherwise made known to it by the Disclosing Party, except to the extent such disclosure or use is expressly permitted by the terms of this Agreement or is reasonably necessary for the performance of, or the exercise of such Party's rights under, this Agreement; provided that such parties to which the Confidential Information is disclosed are bound by written obligations of confidentiality at least as stringent as those set forth in this Agreement. Notwithstanding the foregoing, a Receiving Party will remain liable for any breach of this Article 10 (Confidentiality) by any party to whom the Receiving Party has disclosed the Disclosing Party's Confidential Information under this Section 10.2 (Confidential Treatment).
perturbation.changed_text: 10.2 Confidential Treatment. At all times during the Term and for a period of 1 year following the end of the Term, or with respect to trade secrets (with such trade secrets either (i) having been specifically identified in writing to the Receiving Party by the Disclosing Party claiming ownership of the same or (ii) reasonably distinguishable by its nature or content as a trade secret of the Disclosing Party), until such time that such information is no longer a trade secret (including pursuant to Sections 10.1.1 - 10.1.5), Receiving Party will, and will cause its Affiliates and its and their respective officers, directors, employees, Permitted Subcontractors, permitted sublicensees and agents to, keep confidential and not publish or otherwise disclose to a Third Party and not use for any purpose, any Confidential Information furnished or otherwise made known to it by the Disclosing Party, except to the extent such disclosure or use is expressly permitted by the terms of this Agreement or is reasonably necessary for the performance of, or the exercise of such Party's rights under, this Agreement; provided that such parties to which the Confidential Information is disclosed are bound by written obligations of confidentiality at least as stringent as those set forth in this Agreement. Notwithstanding the foregoing, a Receiving Party will remain liable for any breach of this Article 10 (Confidentiality) by any party to whom the Receiving Party has disclosed the Disclosing Party's Confidential Information under this Section 10.2 (Confidential Treatment).
perturbation.explanation: Trade secrets are protected indefinitely as long as they remain secret and provide a competitive advantage. By limiting the confidentiality period for all information, including trade secrets, to just one year, the contract fails to provide adequate protection for trade secrets, potentially violating state laws protecting such information.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Uniform Trade Secrets Act - Cal. Civ. Code ยง 3426

perturbation.original_text: If the breaching Party fails to cure such breach within sixty (60) days after such notice, then the non-breaching Party may terminate this Agreement upon written notice to the breaching Party in its entirety. Notwithstanding the foregoing, if the breaching Party has a bona fide dispute as to whether such breach has occurred or has been cured, it will so notify the non- breaching Party in writing and the cure period will be tolled until such dispute is resolved pursuant to Section 14.5.2 (Dispute Resolution). Upon a final determination of breach or failure to cure, the breaching Party will have the remainder of the cure period to cure such breach. [***].
perturbation.changed_text: If the breaching Party fails to cure such breach within fifteen (15) days after such notice, then the non-breaching Party may terminate this Agreement upon written notice to the breaching Party in its entirety. Notwithstanding the foregoing, if the breaching Party has a bona fide dispute as to whether such breach has occurred or has been cured, it will so notify the non- breaching Party in writing and the cure period will be tolled until such dispute is resolved pursuant to Section 14.5.2 (Dispute Resolution). Upon a final determination of breach or failure to cure, the breaching Party will have the remainder of the cure period to cure such breach. [***].
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the cure period for a material breach to 15 days may be considered unreasonably short, especially for complex breaches, potentially violating principles of good faith and fair dealing implied in contract law. Some jurisdictions could deem this insufficient, making the termination clause unenforceable.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Implied Covenant of Good Faith and Fair Dealing - General Contract Law Principles
